awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Similarity based interference and the acquisition of adjunct control
awd_abstract_narration:
Every community around the world has a language. In each community, within a few years and with high accuracy, children learn the language of their environment. Achieving high proficiency in at least one language is critical for learning the culture of the community, connecting with peers, and accessing an education. When language is delayed, other aspects of development may also be at risk. Studying how language develops in children is therefore of great importance, both for understanding how language interacts with other systems, and for identifying and diagnosing language delays. Although children learn language quickly, they continue to make some errors well after they achieve high proficiency in their first language. These errors, because they are so rare, provide useful insights into the mechanisms of language development. Many of the general cognitive processes proposed to interact with language in adults are known to develop much later than language, raising the question: to what extent are children's linguistic errors due to extra-linguistic processes, rather than incomplete linguistic knowledge?

This research uses children's understanding of adjunct control, as in "John bumped Mary after tripping on the sidewalk," as a case study to investigate this question. For this sentence, adults only access a meaning in which John tripped, while children have been reported to exhibit a much wider range of interpretations, in which John, Mary or anyone tripped. All accounts to date of adjunct control in children have cited incomplete knowledge as the source of children's interpretations; this research pursues an alternative account--that children's knowledge is complete, but the extra-linguistic processing mechanisms are more error-prone in children than in adults, masking children's knowledge in contexts with a high processing load. Based on the manipulations used with similar types of sentences in adult sentence processing, this research investigates the effects of processing load on children's interpretations of sentences with adjunct control. At stake is a more continuous account that relates children's errors for adjunct control to parallel effects in adults, and presents the opportunity for future research to investigate other sentence types, the development of processing mechanisms, and how immature processing mechanisms affect language development. This research also includes an outreach component to local families and high schools, and will provide research experience to an undergraduate research assistant.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Children are tasked with acquiring complete knowledge of their first language based on incomplete experience with the language. At the same time, other general cognitive processes develop alongside children's language, many of which are known to interact with language in adults. This project investigated the role of these extra-linguistic processes in language acquisition.

The focus of the project was on the mistakes that children make during language acquisition, which may be due to incomplete linguistic knowledge or the interaction between linguistic knowledge and immature cognitive processes. Teasing these apart can be informative for understanding typical development, and for identifying and diagnosing language delays. This project focused on mistakes which have previously been linked to incomplete linguistic knowledge, and considered the influence of immature parsing mechanisms as a source of children's errors. With parallel effects observed in adult sentence processing, this allows for a more continuous developmental trajectory for various structures.

For this project, sentences with adjunct control (as in (1)) were used as a case study to ask about the influence of extra-linguistic processes in children's errors.

(1)   John called Mary before running to the store.

The sentence in (1) is generally interpreted to mean that John ran to the store, and not that Mary ran to the store. Meanwhile, children have been reported to allow a wider range of interpretations - that Mary, John or Mary, or anyone ran to the store.

Arriving at an interpretation for (1) involves storing "John" and "Mary" in memory, and then retrieving "John" from memory later on. Meanwhile, difficulty with retrieval is often observed when similar items are stored in memory, due to interference between the items. We manipulated the similarity between items in sentences with adjunct control, and found that children made fewer errors when the items were less similar to each other. This suggests that interference in memory influences children's behavior for adjunct control.

In a set of follow-up experiments, we asked how much of children's behavior with adjunct control was explained by interference effects. We found that children's behavior also varied in different task contexts; these contexts may interact differently with the processes involved in interference.

More generally, these results may be linked to interference effects observed for other structures with children and adults, and may help to shed light on specific parsing processes as well as the development of these processes themselves. Gaining a greater understanding of both of these is important for understanding processing difficulties throughout development and beyond, which may contribute to interventions for improving processing and understanding in practical settings.


Last Modified: 12/22/2018
Modified by: Juliana Gerard
